pros: Good research environment, lots of support
cons: Unclear career progression chance in long-term

review_title: Great company, supportive team, but long hours
pros: Fantastic company to work for - being a Russell Group university our team helps contribute to ground breaking research and get to be involved in a lot of strategic projects. Lovely campus. Flexible working across the whole company with 3.5 "core hours" a day (for full time staff) and the other hours you can make up as you wish (within reason). Great annual leave. Two extra closure days at Easter, and four between Christmas and New Year. Ability to purchase extra holiday on top of all of this, and they introduced the ability to apply for domestic leave during the pandemic. We have had several pay rises in the last 12 months! Hybrid working seems common and accepted across the University with each team/department having their own charter and arrangements. Many office-based staff work the majority from home but for those who prefer the office, there is plenty of space available although meeting rooms are difficult to book, for private Teams calls.
cons: Long hours - the base hours for L4s and over is 35 hours a week / 7 hours a day, but in reality many do 38-50 hours either ad hoc or over the long term, and might struggle to book off holiday.

job_title: Clinical Trial Assistant in Southampton, England
pros: Good team, hub of research
cons: I have no cons at a present

review_title: An Unforgettable Workplace: Where Professional Growth and Team Culture Thrive!
pros: Encouraging and supportive management team who actively invests in the development of their employees. Positive and inclusive work environment that fosters collaboration and teamwork. Opportunities for career advancement and ongoing learning through training and development programs. Employee recognition and appreciation programs that recognize hard work and dedication. A strong sense of community within the workplace that is built upon shared values and a commitment to excellence. Innovative and forward-thinking company culture that encourages creativity and new ideas. Commitment to corporate social responsibility and making a positive impact in the world. Open communication channels and transparent feedback processes that promote honest and constructive conversations.
cons: Workload can be demanding and stressful, especially during busy periods or tight deadlines. Some employees may feel pressure to work long hours to keep up with workload and meet expectations. Some team members may be more competitive than collaborative, which can create a less cohesive team dynamic. The physical workspace may not be ideal for all employees, with limited amenities or distractions that may impact productivity. Benefits and compensation packages may not be as competitive as other companies in the industry.

pros: The work environment is really halthy

Training programs for graduate school are below par, and you rely completely on peers.

pros: I worked with the best supervisors and colleagues. They gave me every opportunity.
cons: They made financial errors where they overpaid my stipend over two years by £5000 and expected me to pay it back within one year. They lost the money that I had earned through my consultancies with the UK Government, which would have fully paid my debt off. They never reply to emails or said sorry about any of this. After working there for 4 years, I got no goodbye card.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Southampton, England
pros:
- a very good experience overall, with challenging projects, even as an undergraduate student
- even as an undergrad, you're not just doing the small tasks, you are an integral contributor, so you end up gaining a very valuable skill set
- since it's research based, it does give you a very good insight into academia very early on
- especially as an intern, management is really understanding regarding university workload, so you can very easily balance university studies with the work you have to do
- personally, I recommend this type of work for anyone that thinks about going into research or academia
cons: - if the project lacks funding and gets cancelled, it could take some time to get transferred into another one, though that was heavily influenced by Covid-19 at the time

review_title: Pays a wage, but don't expect compassion or decency
pros: A few people, notably Vaughan Martin the Fire Safety Manager, truly care about their jobs and the people around them.
cons:
Harassment goes unchecked - or the victim gets moved while the perpetrator goes on untouched. Even physical threats of violence can be ignored. Then again, when managers have been known to shout at crying employees in public corridors, where not just staff but other students can see, this might be expected.

Despite claims of diversity, simple factors like keeping toilets clean, safe and accessible are not really important to management, and diversity training that was supposed to be rolled out across sites was cancelled. Alternate training by an ex-police officer included incorrect statements about the Equality Act 2010, bigoted statements, and actions that drove one person in a group training session into a panic attack. When multiple people raised concerns to management, they were ignored. When concerns were raised about new uniform plans that were sexist, culturally insensitive and inaccessible to members of multiple religions, those who raised them were pulled aside for meetings in which they were talked down to and told that plans would not be changing as it was felt that enough discussions had already been had.

Manager might agree to reasonable accommodations under the Equality Act, but it doesn't mean that they'll keep to them. Employees who do ask for accommodations may also be told that no other job would ever accept them, so they should be grateful to have employment at all - even as they are actively being harassed.

Talking to a high level member of management about diversity issues caused them to quite literally laugh in my face.

And as for the safety of its volunteers, well, Vaughan Martin certainly believes in his job. A good thing to, because after middle management told general assistants to falsify health and safety records regarding the fire safety of a building, Vaughan Martin responded to contact and came down to make sure that management had the building made safe and fire exits cleared. Management were noticeably angry with the general assistants for several days, but as they couldn't identify the whistleblower for certain no recriminations ever occurred.

pros:
Good pension scheme, but it seems like that is in question in future.

Good holiday allowance - you need it!
cons:
EVERYBODY reaches a point about one year after joining the university where they are just defeated by the endless bureaucracy and slow pace of movement or change. They give up . They stop trying to make a difference because they get nowhere, it's like a light in their soul goes out. They either look for a new job or just suck it up and do the bare minimum work. I've seen this happen to at least a dozen people.

You can't change the way the uni operates. Hundreds of people have tried and failed. There is no dynamism or morale. It's just soul-killing.

review_title: Terrible place to work now, toxic environment
pros: Work life balance, shorter working hours, work from home, great colleagues
cons: Terrible Senior Management from the Vice chancellor down to the assistant directors of isolutions. Everyones a yes man, no one wants to tell the truth to the person above for fear of reprisals. Culture of bullying is still well alive, and lip service is paid to addressing bullying. No one has confidence in the leadership team which is actually lower than a couple of years ago under the previous director. That felt like we were all in a driverless car, but at least someone else in the car could grab the wheel to steer us around a dangerous bend when needed. This is more like the driver is drunk and deliberately trying to crash us into the wall.

pros: The students are great and most of the team were fun and friendly.
cons: The management structure leads to people with no experience managing very small numbers of staff completely unchecked. I was bullied and harassed out of my job and failed to get any support from management or HR. I have since contacted HR as they left me completely unsupported which had a serious effect on my wellbeing. This was escalated over 6 months ago and I still haven't been contacted.

pros:
Pay was good for what we where doing. 
Staff where friendly and supportive. 
Easy interview process.
cons:
Pay came a long time after the job was over. 
Can be hard to keep up if you also study.

pros: Flexibility of working, especially on the academic side. Fantastic atmosphere on campus when students are around, and very peaceful when they are not. Work with very smart people.
cons:
Variable career support from management; the academic pathway is very competitive, and it feels like there is not much room to progress upwards. If your manager is a professor, their time is likely split dozens of different ways, which makes it hard to feel like they care about your development.

The job expands to fit all available time. If you teach, then you just have to get prepared by the time of the lecture, regardless of how much notice you're given or how many resources you have to research and develop! If you research, there are immoveable grant and paper deadlines, which again have to be met. It can make the work pattern very irregular, with some very stressful periods and some very quiet periods.

The pay is not great on the lower levels, but if you can progress past the various level barriers, it can become decent and employment is relatively secure. It offers quite a lot of flexibility, but demands a lot, so I guess you have to decide whether that flexibility is worth the periodic stress and compensation that's lower than industry.

pros: Southampton is quite close to London, and the University offers many opportunities.
cons: The University is weighed by a troubled managerial past.

pros: friendly staff and intersting work
cons: i had to write five words to submit the form

review_title: COVID Guidelines have unfortunately ruined the university experience

Staff and students are friendly

Online classes are less frequent than normal lectures and don't cover the content fully
No practical elements - it makes engineering difficult

pros: A collaborative environment. There are many exciting research groups.

pros: Interesting, Environment, Coworkers, Social, Engaging

pros: Great staff and support network
cons: pay to park, none at all

pros: Inclusive, welcoming, green, campus, freindly
cons: No cons, had no bad experiences, would work there again

review_title: Over worked, under paid and not adequately trained
pros: Opportunities to be part of research cruises. Demonstrator pay is good.  Lots of help with publishing papers. Lots of travel to international conferences.
cons: Work very long hours and weekends, 70 hour weeks are common that leads to high anxiety and poor mental health. Burnout and depression were very common with the PhD students. Expected to do a variety of unrelated complex tasks without being trained in it. There was a lot of self-teaching through google and mistake making that could have been avoided if supervisors would help more. They do not pay you long enough to cover your writing time and corrections, I had to work unpaid for a year after the funding was finished to complete the thesis and its corrections. Getting refunds for travel expenses can take two months, and being paid for demonstrating can also take six months.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Southampton, England
pros: Generous holiday allowance. Campus is nice enough, with relatively easy access to the city centre and surrounding areas by bus, although train connections are a bit more challenging. Also easy access to a variety of Chinese food restaurants nearby.
cons: Administration appears to care little for the impact of their policies on researchers. Little opportunity for early career researchers to distinguish themselves, however, this has been improving as of late. The amount of paperwork, harassment and bureaucracy imposed by health and safety is a significant impediment to performing research. Hired technical staff does not have sufficient background and expertise to perform their jobs at a reasonable standard.

review_title: Good academic staff, poor management and administration
pros: There are good academic staff in the university, although many are leaving because of the horrible management.
cons: The administration act as though the university is there for their benefit, and not for producing research and educating students.  Human resources imposes policies on academic hiring that are not appropriate to academic hiring (e.g. not requesting letters of reference until a short list is made).  Management, from the rank of associate dean up, is generally full of either people who try to micromanage things without understanding the implications of their policies, or their toadies.

review_title: Great research university somewhat lacking structure and postgraduate representation
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Southampton, England
pros:
- Russell Group status
- Research is well-funded and tends to be quite novel
- Friendly university
- Highfield campus has a lot going on, and is visually appealing
- Plenty of societies
- Some professors/lecturers leaders within their fields
- University bus service is regular and the routes are quite good
cons:
- Faculty organisation is abysmal; communication with students especially dire in Faculty of Medicine and Faculty of Health Sciences
- Student Union either mis-manage budget or are under-funded
- Disjointed feeling between satellite campuses
- Postgraduate students are under represented, although this has gotten better over the past year
- Clique behaviour and favorutism between staff members is noticeable
- Supervisors in managerial positions have not necessarily had the correct training, and so subordinates feel disgruntled and poorly managed

review_title: Student Ambassador - work experience, ok pay and good fun
pros:
In this job you can
- Gain useful experience for your CV
- Connect with other university students you might not otherwise meet
- Network at university events and careers fairs
- Meet potential students who are usually very nice
- Only sign up for the shifts that suit you to fit around your studies
- Potentially be promoted to Senior Ambassador, getting more responsibility  and a leadership role
- Be lead by respectful University full-time employees who make you feel valued
cons: There were not any cons really. Nice, gentle part time job that provided me with extra cash and some useful points to include on my CV. Maybe a little disorganised at times. But that sometimes can't be avoided at busy events.

pros: Relaxed working environment, highly skilled colleagues, flexible working arrangements with agreement.
cons:
Limited career progression, 'dead mans shoes' is the only way to progress, some instances of employees leaving then reapplying for their old job at a higher paygrade. The VC (Nutbeam) seems totally out of touch with the University; drives a hard line on refusing lecturer pay increases whilst accepting a ~£30k pay rise in the same year the University slips in the rankings.
Within our department, 'restructuring' is the preferred way for Senior Management to change their titles and pay without actually increasing workload.

pros: Had a good supervisory team, who helped and aided me along the way. I was on the A*STAR attachment programme with two years in Singapore. Though more bureaucratic than studying in the UK, they have fantastic facilities and a lot of talented people.
cons: I had a really great supervisor during my Singapore attachment, and I learnt a lot from him. However, other students had different experiences whereby there was a big disconnect between the UK and Singapore, which was unhelpful in the PhD progression.

review_title: Go be a Student Ambassador. And absolutely love it!
pros: Being a Student Ambassador can be great fun and really rewarding, on a personal level, if you like Outreach work or earning money or both. Career-wise, it can give you so many ideas, if you are inclined towards Welfare and/ or academic/ teaching/ work; it would also be fantastic to have it on your CV if you want to go into a sector involving work with young people.
cons: Cannot think of much, except for probably salary raise not being competitive, when compared to some other Universities, or over the last couple of years.

review_title: a university with no commitment to training ?!
pros:
Excellent friendly and capable team 
Flexible and supportive of part time or flexible working requests
Excellent holiday allowance and closure days Christmas and Easter 
Lovely green campus
cons:
Training is non existent. 
Jobs don’t tend to challenge - potential restricted by management and archaic culture 
Lack of investment in staff facilities and estate (offices not hoovered, dirty/shared workstations, no kitchenettes or staff areas)
Doesn’t allow trailblazers or competent people to shake things up
Academic culture - can be very patronising and offensive

pros: There is a enormous potential working at the university.  So many great people that can carry off the ideas and the initiatives that the senior management may have.  I would say that one of their greatest strengths is the depth of knowledge that many of their staff at all levels have.  And if you're in the right place, there are some great opportunities for bringing ideas to life for research, education and enterprise.
cons: There can be inconsistencies of experience for staff, depending on who they work for.  Such a vast place would inevitably have competing agendas but this is changing.  Much more equality of opportunity.

pros: Good Pension and subsidised bus
cons: Too much nepotism. Several members of staff are related to each other or in a relationship. Incompetent bunch in professional services. People just drag their feet. There are people there who graduated at the University, got a job at the University and have been there for over 20 years, without never getting out of Southampton and getting experience elsewhere. People just do the minimal and tend to bully anyone who wants to do a good job. Work-life balance depends on how much management likes or dislikes you.

pros: The teaching academics and staff I have worked with in ECS genuinely seem to care about the students and want to give them a good teaching experience. There is a lot of emphasis on getting the proper training and paid for all hours worked.
cons: As a demonstrator and PhD student sometimes the work load can be mount up. Marking can also be quite inconsistent between demonstrators that can make for unhappy undergraduate students when they rightly consider their marks unfair.

review_title: Working in academia is hard because of bike shedding and penny pinching.
pros: Great research, smart people, vibrant students with a willingness to learn and teach you in return.
cons:
Admin. The administration are the slowest, laziest kinds of people. Jobsworths through and through with no idea what the big picture is and intention to figure it out.

The pointless Bureaucracy that is eating academia from the inside out is in full force in southampton.

review_title: Great company to work for if you work in one of the offices, not so much in the field
job_title: Field Sales Development Executive in London, England
pros: Great company culture, good support, great benefits and incentives
cons:
Field sales is a lonely job where it's difficult to hit targets. Also the company insists on silly 'steps to the call' to employ in a sales conversation which, in my experience, negatively affected my relationship with my customers. 
Also they preach that experience and movement to different departments is both available and supported, however this was not true

pros: The campus is great and constantly evolving. The research facility for my PhD was world-class. My colleagues were knowledgeable and thriving for the best research.
cons: Some oddities on campus such as food prices that are higher than outside of campus. Sometimes the administration can be tedious but in general every problem is solved in reasonable time. The city of Southampton is not great although it is experiencing a lot of change for the better.

pros: Genuinely changing the world. Going places, getting its act together. If you have ideas people will take them seriously. Big enough to count. Small enough that you get to know the right people. Generous leave. Supportive & developmental culture. Easy motorway access. Nice campus. Nursery
cons: Standard HE pay. Poor reputation of city. Not enough public speaker events. Insufficient internal comms. No subsidised staff education. Odd intranet setup. Incorrect ceo listed on glass door.

pros:
The staff are alright. Southampton is not a very bad place to live in but you can get bored easily.
If you prefer a quiet life then Southampton is for you. The UNiversity itself is prestigious and one of the top Universities in the country.
cons:
They need to put more effort into managign funds when it comes to student projects especially in engineering.
Students should be encouraged to participate in moe technical projects.

review_title: Experiences may vary, but this is mine...
pros: In our team, we have autonomy to work as we see best, and this includes planning and delivering work to students. Great colleagues, it's actually fun to come to work each day!
cons: Lack of clear management in some areas where it's needed. Also, things tend to happen quite slowly, but that's rather common in public sector in the UK.

review_title: Interesting advanced research opportunities, but limited advancement opportunities
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Southampton, England
pros:
Really outstanding research opportunities in engineering and science
Wonderfully diverse student and staff
Collaborative environment
Lively student body and well-organized extra-curricular activities
cons: Like many universities, facing difficult fiscal times.  Resource limitations result in inter-departmental struggles and top-down management.  The city of Southampton itself is not terribly pleasant, but the surrounding countryside and proximity to London make it more attractive.

pros: They provide training in most current sales methods that is used by today's tech companies. From day one, Launchsource builds a relationship to be able to prepare and place you with a company that you can succeed with. They place an emphasis on matching company culture to ensure you start your career with an opportunity that will fit you. I've found the management to be approachable and the CEO to be personal and look out for the employee's best interests.
cons: I have not had negative experiences since starting at LaunchSource.

pros: Decent access to publications, new building/facilities, close knit department. Decent seminar programmes. A few big names in the department
cons: Poor IT support, lack of working space, cannot access some journals (even some high impact ones), not as much technical support as one would like sometimes. Also the hospital lab facilities are old and in great need of updating.

review_title: Highly dependant on department and direct management
pros:
I personally experienced a great work life balance and brilliant support from my direct managers. 
The general work environment is a pleasure and for the most part everyone works together.
cons:
Career progression in academia is extremely competitive and the success/failure of a single project can  significantly affect your prospects 
The support infrastructure is abhorrent. Legal, travel, expenses, IT are all a hindrance and most of the time it feels like it takes more effort than handling it myself.

pros: You get to choose when and how you want to work. All of the jobs will be sent via email and anyone interested in working for the email just have to reply back.
cons: Its very hard to track all of the jobs within the outreach office. And sometimes you will be rejected for roles which will deter ambassadors from requesting tasks.

pros: flexible working hours, some fantastic colleagues, good pension scheme, fair annual leave allowance plus university closure days, some bonuses available, internal cpd available.
cons: No support for external CPD or even to study with the Uni itself, organisational values aren't acted upon, some people overworked to make up of mediocrity of others.

pros:
- Good employer
- Nice working environment
- Interesting colleagues
- Interesting clients/users
- Feeling that I am working on things that are important and useful
- Good pay
- Excellent holiday and benefits
- Progressive and sympathetic employer
- I have good resources and a superb kit (my personal IT kit and the systems I support are modern and well maintained).
cons: Quite honestly I don't have any.

pros: Easy to fit around studies, very good fun as well as being useful for developing a number of key skills in event management and communication. So enjoyable it hardly feels like work.
cons: Prior to some of the larger events they require you to attend "training" sessions - often unpaid - which are usually just the event organiser showing a powerpoint which could have easily been e-mailed to the student ambassadors. They waste time and are of little use.

pros:
Excellent access to training, development and skills workshops
Excellent access to research projects and apex technologies
Excellent access to publication and recognition of work
Excellent flexibility
cons:
Salaries are beyond ridiculous for the work put in (low end)
The competency of and restrictions from management is a complete lottery

pros:
Exactly the sort of job I wanted at the time. Was very quick to sort out paperwork to get me in and working. I had the opportunity to extend my contract if I wanted to.
Amazing, friendly people.
Very intellectual and ambitious colleagues.
cons:
Hesitant to change.
Slow to enact processes.
Negative attitudes always expressed first.

review_title: A good place to do a PhD - Would recommend
pros: Good facilities and connections with industry. Lots of opportunities for inter-department collaborations
cons: Limited support for PhD students beyond academic needs (e.g. well being and mental health) - some support does exist, but lots of room for improvement.

pros: Get to do what you want, a lot of freedom. But I guess it's pretty much the same everywhere in a university. Engineering research in Southampton is very well know so there are quite a few industrial corporations going on, that might be helpful if you are seeking an industry move afterwards.
cons: You are pretty much working on your own, the city isn't the most interesting one in UK. It depends on what your expectations are for a university really.

pros: Some of the most amazing research you will ever find, lovely main campus, fabulous degree shows at the School of Art.
cons: Very STEM centric research and education, mediocre middle management, too many systems. Progression in career in professional services and other non academic jobs is difficult, as very different to academic progression routes.

pros: Facilities are good. I particularly like the library. Campus in a relatively student friendly city. Reputed and highly ranked in many subjects
cons: Passive bullying both by boss and my colleagues. I had terrible time with the boss. No set review/appraisal as promised at the time of joining. Don't consider this as an equal opportunity environment

review_title: Intense University heavily involved with industry
pros:
- A lot of services working almost instantly (technical, career advice etc.)
- Heavy involvement with industry, lots of training and seminars taking place for career advancement and networking
- Interesting talks from visiting scholars
- Lots of opportunities for undergrads to form teams and participate in competitions
- Start-up incubator
- Good health services
cons:
- A few of the supervisors had very bad behaviour
- Unhealthy competition between some groups
- Less academic environment

pros:
Job security super
 nice team if team manager is good.
Campus life 
Big pension big holodays
WFH and good balance
cons:
No career progress for professional services staff
Job security means people become lazy after few years
Lower management is underpaid so hard to find a proper one 
Some dept moved out of campus

pros: Very flexible working hours depending on supervisor. As long as the research is done you can come and go pretty much as you please.
cons:
Limited careers advice unless you seek it out yourself.
Very 'academic' working environment, quiet office might not be for everyone.

review_title: An interesting, vibrant place to work.
job_title: Learning Support Assistant in Southampton, England
pros: Lots of interesting, busy people, lots going on, main campus on nice park with lots of trees and flowers. Staff seem really engaged with their work. A top-ranking Russell Group university, doing lots of groundbreaking research in all sorts of areas.
cons: For someone on a zero hours contract such as myself, the usual variability of work.

job_title: PhD Research Student in Southampton, England
pros: Travelling a lot is a great benefit. There is a huge amount of freedom and flexibility in working hours and decisions about your work.
cons: The pressure to publish all results can very quickly become very daunting. One often feels the need to finish off projects which become less interesting or simply impossible to achieve.

review_title: Valued employee at a world-class institution
pros: Vibrant campus setting; 30 days annual leave + bank holidays + 6 additional closure days; good emphasis on work-life balance; USS pension; opportunities to work in different professional departments; sabbatical leave possibilities; competent management; affordable accommodation in a lively city
cons: Vice-Chancellor's pay increases disproportionately; offices can be crowded; not situated conveniently for either of Southampton's stations

pros: The University offers state of the art facilities for both experimentation and computations. The location is good.
cons: Most of the colleagues around you have little or no ambitions to improve things, and do better just because it is part of our job to do so.

review_title: General Assistant with Residences via Tempbank (now UniWorkforce)
pros:
Really, genuinely pleasant atmosphere

With exception to specific times of year (around intake for example), hours are consistent with very few late finishes
cons: On occasion, some degree of confusion around a task due to hearing different things from diffferent people, although this is often addressed quickly

job_title: Library Reception Support in Southampton, England
pros: my job was easy and based on routine tasks and there weren't any targets or deadlines. So it was really relaxed although it was at the library reception but there was no pressure at all. The morning reception supervisor was the best manager in the world very friendly and kind and always appreciating our work.
cons: no chance for progression. no challenges as well

job_title: PhD Student in City of London, England
pros:
environment is perfect and salary is very good.
team member is good.
Hope more people join in my university and good luck
cons:
the city is too  small and have no fun in the city.
Moreover, there are not too many big company in Southampton

pros: Very good time, met lots of nice people and decent pay. I really thouroughly enjoyed my time working there.
cons: There was only the opportunity for a small amount of hours and some weeks you got no opportunities at all

pros: Historically a university with high UK standing
cons:
Endless reorganisations
Pointless bean counting and regulatory procedures
Top management obsessed with external performance indicators
Increasing student numbers without forward planning
Blaming teaching staff when they are not responsible for  teaching rooms or timetabling  or student union inadequacies
Low staff morale because of all above

pros: Lovely people, very creative and stimulating environment.  Beautiful estate at Highfield.
cons:
Too many restructures and new ideas that don't bed in.
Better career prospects, jobs and pay reward for academics than the professional services.

pros: Freedom, personal growth, excellent equipment and research teams. Campus is very nice, national parks nearby are beautiful. Would consider living in winchester and commuting however
cons: Salary, work-life balance. Local town is quite poor, food on campus is bad, can be quite boring place to work. Not a lot of outside social organisation.

pros:
+very international
+good campus life style
+good engineering department
+had a great supervisor
+international traveling (US, europe) several times a year
+free vacation planing makes life more free
cons:
+high stress load due to publication pressure, but, as PhD student normal
+no stress no glory...

pros:
Independently responsible for workload
Workshops are accessible by staff to use during research time & summer periods
A satisfactory pay spline increment every year
cons:
Sharing of quality teaching and learning is not high on the agenda.
Departments and staff very independent from one another.
Some outdated practice still prevalent by older members of staff

pros: Very flexible working hours for a student , get to work with lots of new people. Work usually involves showing students around and telling them about facilities and student life.
cons: The job is given on rolling basis, so you should be able to answer your emails quickly.

pros: research orientated, supportive, provides opportunities to network with scholars from top institutes.
cons: despite of the research orientated atmosphere, some scholars here (Business School) seem a bit lack of the desire of publishing in top journals and satisfied with want their current level of academic achievement.

review_title: Great benefits but lots of change
pros: Great people and the benefits of working at a university are very good (leave, pension, flexible working)
cons: There is a lot of change happening (new leadership, restructuring, drive to save money) which can be  disruptive and lead to concerns about job security

pros: Amazing place, where innovation is flourishing. The people are great as well and are taking care of each other. Lots of fun
cons: It is part of the university so sometimes simple things are overly complicated - e.g. purchasing new machines

pros: Well-reputable higher education establishment with strong resreach orientation. Extensively developed EAP presessional course syllabus and materials accompsnied with the effective EAP toolkit to support students throughout their studies.
cons: Course B is Extremely intense, which requires full-time commitment and extra preparation work during weekends

pros: - good atmosphere, dynamic environment, helpful people - but this is down to certain people, not the organisation as such
cons: - too much corporational stuff everywhere, too much central planning, but probably there are necessary for companies of that size

pros: Offer flexible working which is great for working parents. Offers closure days over holiday periods.
cons: If you're working within a company that the Uni has tendered for, you might find yourself looking for another position if you don't fall under the redeployment scheme.

pros: working with people, Easy hours, very flexible can fit it around classes
cons: Sometimes there is not enough information about what you are doing and you need to figure out a lot by yourself.

pros: Nice environment, full of students from any part of the world, the campus is amazing and the students societies are very motivated to organise activities rgarding sport, arts etc.
cons: The city itself is boring, the only interesting thing is the university

review_title: Good employer but focus on research
pros: Good people policies, good benefits, nice environment. Improving sustainability and environmental policies.
cons: Focused on Research and Education with the Professional Services being a little left behind! Very hierarchical structure.

pros: Work hard, play hard, work harder. The community at Southampton Uni is amazing
cons: Not as famous as other institutions even though the research is world leading

review_title: The University is going through major changes
job_title: Country Development Manager in Southampton, England
pros: Challenging and rewarding job, supportive managers. Positive 10-year plan under the new VC.
cons: The University is going through major changes under the new VC so it is rather unsettling environment at the moment.

job_title: PhD Research Student in Southampton, England
pros: Great staffs, many scholarship opportunities, mental health support, gym is great, various research groups and international collaboration
cons: library is small, sometimes it's hard to find a place to sit and study during exam time.

pros: Excellent Pension, leave, work life balance
cons: Very bureaucratic and slow to make changes or to take risks

job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Southampton, England
pros: Flexible time managing and good balance work/life.
cons: There are not disadvantage other than making sure you accomplish with specific deadlines.

pros: Great Pension plan, flexibilities of work time and great annual leave days.
cons: Salary is far less than market rate, slow and messy working environment

review_title: Limited progression, but otherwise good place to work
pros: Salary competitive, work life balance is generally promoted, and good accommodations for people such as parental leave etc.
